item.title: I Hope My Outer Worlds 2 Companions Really Do Try To Kill Me
item.content:encoded:
Companions in the original Outer Worlds were kind of stiff. You could build up your relationships with them. They‚Äôd tell you when they were unhappy. But none of it ever led anywhere. They amounted to a fire-suppressing peanut gallery that helped you learn about and reflect on the world around you but little more. The Outer Worlds 2 will try to fix that. You still can‚Äôt romance companions in the sequel but at least they‚Äôll try to kill you this time if you really piss them off.

You‚Äôll have six optional companions in Obsidian‚Äôs upcoming sci-fi RPG, many associated with particular in-game factions. Niles is an engineer from the Earth Directorate. Valerie is a robot from the same faction. Aza is a cultist from the Glorious Dawn. Inez is a field medic from Auntie‚Äôs Choice. Marisol is an assassin from the Order of the Ascendant. Finally there‚Äôs Tristan from the Protectorate who has a giant hammer. Hurt their friends or break their rules and they‚Äôll turn on you.

‚ÄúOne of the things that was really important is we wanted these characters to feel like they‚Äôre their own people,‚Äù design director Matt Singh said on the latest episode of the Xbox Expansion Pass show (via Gamesradar). ‚ÄúThey have their own goals, their own motivations, and if the player‚Äôs aligning with them, that‚Äôs great. They‚Äôre going to be there for you. They‚Äôll fight alongside you. But if you go against their interests, they‚Äôre going to have something to say about it. That might break out into a conflict, that might mean they leave you or you have to fight them to the death. But if you do build that relationship with them, they‚Äôll be there for you in the end.‚Äù

This sounds neat and builds off one of the most memorable moments from the original Mass Effect in which two of your squadmates clash, resulting in an unreconcilable showdown. Over a decade later I still remember what choice I made during that part of the game and why (fuck you, Ashley). I don‚Äôt expect The Outer Worlds 2 to rise to the same level since these confrontations don‚Äôt sound like pivotal scripted moments so much as procedural consequences.

Singh also suggests you can sort of skate by the friction if you have a good enough relationship with the NPC. Something like, ‚ÄúUh, sorry I wiped out your clan, remember that time I finished your second loyalty mission though?‚Äù I hope that‚Äôs not the case. I hope we have some real friends-to-enemies journeys out there in Halcyon this time around. One of my biggest complaints with party-based RPGs is that the people you‚Äôre with never seem to quite have a mind of their own outside of sassy retorts and disappointed scowls. It sounds like The Outer Worlds 2 is trying to evolve the formula beyond that.

‚ÄúWe still wanted to make sure that the player has choice‚Äîmeaningful choice‚Äîhere,‚Äù Singh told RPGSite in another interview. ‚ÄúCompanions are completely optional. If you don‚Äôt want to engage with them, you don‚Äôt have to. But you can take them along and see how that changes your story. Same thing with factions, right? The factions are there. They have their goals. They have their motivations. You can try to side with them. You can try to bring them together. Or you can say, ‚ÄòF it. I‚Äôm going my way. I don‚Äôt care about you. We‚Äôre going to do it the way that I would like.‚Äô We‚Äôre all trying to figure out how to give the player as much player agency as possible and respond to it in interesting ways.‚Äù

item.title: Netflix Catan Movie and TV Rights Secured, Bringing Scavenging and Diplomacy to Streaming
item.content:encoded:
Official Netflix Catan adaptations may be on the horizon. The popular streaming platform has announced it has secured the global rights for film, TV, and unscripted formats of Asmodee's signature resource-gathering board game.

The Netflix Catan Rights Acquisition

In an official post on Asmodee's website, they announced Netflix had secured the rights to produce live-action and animated projects based on Catan.

The board game, originally called Settlers of Catan in 1995, is a resource management board game where players secure and gather resources on a bountiful island to gain victory points. It is a wildly popular board game. It has sold over 45 million copies, is currently up to its sixth edition, as well as artisanal, bespoke game piece collections such as Catan Masterpiece.

That straightforward set-up will be the focus of these adaptations. Settlers on the fictional island of Catan navigating landscapes, shifting alliances, managing their limited resources, and dealing with robbers and bandits.

The producers for these projects will include Vertigo Entertainment's Roy Lee, Catan Studio's Pete Fenlon, Asmodee's Darren Kyman, and Guido and Benjamin Teuber. 

Millions of people are enjoying CATAN since it was created and for many, it remains a gateway to modern board gaming. I am thrilled to see the game expanding to a larger audience who will discover the richness of its universe, I find it exciting for the future of the brand.‚Äù said Thomas Koegler, CEO of asmodee. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also a testament that board gaming is truly part of pop culture and a popular form of entertainment in everyone‚Äôs homes, and I am delighted to continue asmodee‚Äôs relationship with Netflix.‚Äù 

  Anyone who has played CATAN knows that the intense strategy at the core of the game has endless opportunities for some serious drama,‚Äù said Jinny Howe, Head of Scripted Series, US and Canada, Netflix. ‚ÄúWe're thrilled to partner across series, features, animation, and games to bring this world to life for hardcore 'Settlers' and new fans alike.

The Netflix Catan announcement seems to be part of the trend of modern Hollywood leveraging recognizable IP for content. This has included turning the board game Clue into a competitive game show, and feature film adaptations of Wizards of the Coast's popular card game, Magic: The Gathering.

This also isn't the first time one of Asmodee's board games got a Netflix adaptation. As part of their 2021 deal with Radar Films, the movie Family Pack released on Netflix in 2024. This adaptation of The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow currently sits at a 38% rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

The citizens of the Paris-inspired setting seem to be going through it, and it means that you‚Äôll find a lot of odd one-liners popping up as you run through the city. 

There‚Äôs much to be said about whether or not Lumiose City feels ‚Äúalive‚Äù in Legends: Z-A, as the small map‚Äôs lack of distinct districts and visual identity has come under fire since the RPG launched last week. Still, you can‚Äôt deny that its people have character. The main cast of Z-A Royale participants and members of Team MZ are some of the most memorable characters Game Freak has put in one of these games. While the nameless denizens of Lumiose City you encounter aren‚Äôt decked out in glitz and glamour like the members of the main cast, they make the most of their screentime, like that one lady in the background of Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness. 

Some of the brief quips you‚Äôll see while running around actually drop surprisingly insightful tidbits, like revealing what‚Äôs happened to characters from Pok√©mon X and Y. item.title: Exclusive: Ghost of Yotei Joins Magic's PlayStation x Secret Lair Crossover
item.content:encoded:
Magic: The Gathering‚Äôs next big collaboration brings PlayStation‚Äôs biggest worlds to the table, with Secret Lair drops inspired by God of War, The Last of Us, Horizon, and Sucker Punch‚Äôs Ghost duology. It follows June‚Äôs record-breaking Final Fantasy set, marking yet another major gaming crossover with Magic.

Fresh off the launch of Ghost of Yotei, we caught up with Jason Connell, Creative Director at Sucker Punch, along with Wizards of the Coast‚Äôs Jacob Covey, Steve Sunu, and Annie Sardelis, to learn how Jin Sakai‚Äôs world was reimagined in card form.

They shared how brushstroke met blade, and how Sucker Punch‚Äôs involvement went far beyond a simple seal of approval. And even more excitingly, IGN has also got an exclusive first look at Ghost of Yotei‚Äôs Atsu card, joining the upcoming PlayStation superdrop.

"Once we had the basics set up, it was a super collaborative process" - Jason Connell, Sucker Punch

A Cardboard Ghost

‚ÄúPart of the fun of working with game studios is the mutual fandom between us‚Äîthere‚Äôs usually a Magic fan or three on their side and a group of fans for their game on our team,‚Äù WOTC Art Director, Jacob Covey, explains.

When it comes to Sucker Punch, there are even a few tournament games being played within the development team.

‚ÄúIt's about 10-12 folks who play monthly, mostly Commander format,‚Äù Jason Connell explains. ‚ÄúA few people who regularly come into the office have decks at their desks just in case the mood ever strikes.‚Äù

As for making it happen, the conversation began a while ago, and it was Wizards who wanted to work on a PlayStation collaboration.

‚ÄúBen Jafari [a manager at WOTC] worked hard to not only make this happen between many different studios at once, but to do it on the same timeline,‚Äù Covey reveals.

‚ÄúWe knew we wanted to work with these iconic PlayStation properties, so it was difficult to narrow it down to just a handful.‚Äù

That initial discussion then fed down to the team at Sucker Punch, Connell said, and it was clear that the two Ghost titles would make for ideal fits.

‚ÄúAcross both the Sucker Punch and PlayStation side, it was pretty clear that Ghost could be a really great fit as one of the featured franchises, though, so it came together pretty naturally once they reached out. We were definitely excited by the idea.‚Äù

The rub? Ghost of Yotei hadn‚Äôt been revealed to the public yet.

Landing a Sucker Punch

‚ÄúOur conversations with Wizards of the Coast began before Yotei had been announced, which we admit was probably frustrating from the Wizards' side since we had to be so cryptic,‚Äù he recalls.

‚ÄúWe just kept saying we had a great idea for a secret card, but then saying we couldn't elaborate yet, and thankfully, they were such great partners that they rebuilt the schedule to accommodate us delivering the information and art for Atsu after we announced the game last year, even though the rest of the cards had been locked in by that point.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe knew the drop would be coming right around Yotei‚Äôs launch, so it felt like a perfect fit to try to get her included, and we‚Äôre grateful it worked out.

"We aim to be authentically rooted in the Ghost universe while giving it our unique spin" - Jacob Covey, WOTC

As for card designs, the Sucker Punch part of the Secret Lair drop incorporates Jin Sakai and Atsu, the two protagonists of both games.

‚ÄúOn the art side, Sucker Punch was very trusting and also involved in helping us remain true to their carefully constructed universe, full of its own untold stories,‚Äù said Covey.

‚ÄúWe aim to be authentically rooted in the Ghost universe while giving it our unique spin, focusing on how the characters and settings relate to the Magic ecosystem and gameplay.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe had some great early conversations with the Wizards team, including an initial kickoff where we just explained the key points of Ghost of Tsushima and sent over some materials from the game,‚Äù Connell adds.

"We explained what we felt was important to capture, even discussed some specific artist names and our overall style. It was really interesting getting a glimpse into their process, meeting artists and writers and directors who oversaw all of the different pieces that go into making a card.

"Once we had the basics set up, it was a super collaborative process. While the actual writing and artist selection happened on the Wizards side, we had a ton of input and chances to provide feedback and went through multiple rounds making sure everyone was happy with the overall look and mechanics for the cards."

One of the ways Wizards and Sucker Punch helped bring Jin Sakai to Magic: The Gathering was to lean into the duality of his fighting styles in Ghost of Tsushima, where he‚Äôs torn between samurai combat and the stealthier ‚ÄòGhost‚Äô path.

"Jin Sakai is about a warrior torn between two identities ‚Äî the honorable samurai and the shadowy Ghost,‚Äù Connell explains.

"From the start, I wanted to capture two ways of approaching encounters in Ghost of Tsushima..." - Annie Sardelis, WOTC

"Wizards of the Coast did a great job capturing this in the card with the Standoff ability, which represents his swordsmanship, while Ghost highlights his stealth and ability to strike fear into his opponents. The rest of the Secret Lair cards that Wizards of The Coast curated for this drop helped show his journey to support that theme: tools of conflict, sacrifice, and shifting control that echo Jin‚Äôs struggle between tradition and survival."

"From the start, I wanted to capture two ways of approaching encounters in Ghost of Tsushima," explains WOTC Senior Game Designer, Annie Sardelis.

"I combined elements of how Magic has classically expressed a lone fighter's skills by only giving that bonus to a single attacker. Since double strike and "can't be blocked" are phrases we've seen time and again on Magic cards, I added the words to help my coworkers become familiar with what I was going for. Flavor words, like flavor text, can help give creative definition to rules text, and we ended up keeping them."

A PlayStation Pantheon

Aside from Ghost of Tsushima and Yotei, there are sets focused on God of War‚Äôs Greek and Norse tales, as well as Horizon Forbidden West and two sets for The Last of Us.

Despite the mix of gods and robot dinosaurs, however, it was the gritty post-apocalyptic tale from Naughty Dog that gave Sardelis the biggest challenge.

"The hardest challenge I signed myself up for are the four "Survivors" Partners from The Last of Us series," she explains.

"I thought it was important to represent all the playable characters in the story, but I also wanted your Commander games to feature the infected. It was tricky to find out how to generate the Fungus Zombie tokens on characters that canonically fight against them!"

"Any player can make infected tokens with Ellie, Brick Master and Abby, Merciless Soldier riffs on cards like "Hunted Dragon" to create an increasing number of tokens. Once that was figured out, the rest of the pieces were designed to complement a token/sacrifice strategy- hopefully in a way that inspires mixing and matching between the two drops!"

As for Commander, it‚Äôs Magic‚Äôs most popular format, and I wanted to know which of the new PlayStation cards would make an ideal choice to helm a 100-card deck.

"If you‚Äôre sitting across from me, I think you can expect me to have an Aloy, Savior of Meridian deck or Jin Sakai, Ghost of Tsushima deck somewhere on me," WOTC Senior Product Designer, Steve Sunu, says.

"Annie Sardelis really hit it out of the park for all these designs, Aloy and Jin specifically feel like the designs were created just for a player like me. Annie‚Äôs an incredible designer, and we were so lucky to have her lend her talent to these new-to-Magic designs."

Magic: The Gathering's Secret Lair x PlayStation Drop launches on October 27, 9 AM PT, at the official Secret Lair website.

Lloyd Coombes is an experienced freelancer in tech, gaming and fitness seen at Polygon, Eurogamer, Macworld, TechRadar and many more. He's a big fan of Magic: The Gathering and other collectible card games, much to his wife's dismay.

This article also includes contributions from Robert Anderson, Senior Commerce Editor for IGN.

item.title: Survey shows young players feel pressured to conform to gender and racial stereotypes
item.content:encoded:
Diego Arg√ºello, Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

October 22, 2025

2 Min Read

Via Pexels creator Artem Podrez

Over half of 1,500 young players surveyed said they're expected to conform to certain behaviors based on gender or race.

This is based on the Teens and Screens Report 2025 (via GamesIndustry.Biz), conducted by the Center of Scholars and Storytellers (CSS) at UCLA. The 1,500 young players' ages ranged from 10 to 24.

Speaking on the issue of fear of harassment in online spaces, the survey found that over half of women and girl gamers felt as though they had to "act a certain way" when gaming because of "gender, race, or other identity."

This was echoed by boys and men, with 64.5 percent feeling a similar pressure to present themselves differently while gaming.

"Overall, across identities, adolescents reported feeling pressure around social conformity, performance or skill expectations, and acting out or counteracting stereotypes," the CSS noted in the study. " The social features that make video games a place for community can also lend themselves to social pressures."

Teen players report wanting more inclusive games

Diversity remains an important subject for younger audiences. 41.6 percent of the surveyed players consider "racial diversity in characters and storylines" when choosing games to play. That being said, 47.8 percent of them said they struggle to find games with characters that represent them‚Äîover half of Asian (55.9 percent) and Hispanic or Latino (56.3 percent) players were especially affected by this issue, the survey says.

Related:The secrets of Dead Cells' smart constraints - Unlocking the Vault #3

Meanwhile, the game and tech industries continue to regress on diversity policies and initiatives. Last year, Microsoft shut down its diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) team. Meta followed suit at the beginning of this year when it released an internal memo announcing the termination of its DEI programs. Reported by Business Insider, the company's vice president of human resources, Janelle Gale, wrote that "the legal and policy landscape surrounding diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in the United States is changing."

In another report, RuneScape studio Jagex was criticized internally after pivoting from Pride Month events starting this year. Last month, Jagex CEO defended the pivot as an "apolitical" decision.

item.title: Of Ash and Steel has been delayed
item.content:encoded:
Just last week, TinyBuildGames and developer Fire & Frost announced that Of Ash and Steel would launch on November 6th, but what a difference a week makes. However, after some more testing the development team has discovered some issues that need additional work, so Of Ash and Steel will not make the November 6th date as planned. The delay is not too long though, with Fire & Frost confirming that the new date is now November 24th.

In a statement, the team wrote, ‚ÄúRight now, we are in the active phase of testing the game before its release, making sure your journey across the island will be as smooth and bug-free as possible. Originally, we announced that your adventure would begin on November 6. However, during testing, our teams discovered several issues that require more time to fix than we initially expected. We‚Äôll need a few extra weeks to properly address these issues. The new release date for Of Ash and Steel is now November 24th, 2025.

Announcing the release date was one of the most exciting and nerve-wracking moments of development, because deep down we feared something like this might happen at the very last moment. And‚Ä¶ it did! Hopefully, you haven‚Äôt booked your vacation around the release just yet. We sincerely apologize for this short delay, and hope you‚Äôll understand our decision. Finally, for those who haven‚Äôt tried the demo yet ‚Äî good news! It will remain available for a while longer, so you still have time to step onto Grayshaft and experience the first hours of your adventure. Thank you for your support, and we‚Äôll see you (just a little later) on Grayshaft!‚Äù

Steam Next Fest was a success for Of Ash and Steel with the demo being one of the best performing demos, and the game has now been wishlishted over 220,000 times. The game is being billed as an old school RPG where players will explore the Kingdom of the Seven without mission markers or overt quest guidance. The demo features part of the main quest, side missions, professions, and upgrades.

item.title: Opinion: Pok√©mon Legends Z-A Is The Creepiest Entry Yet, Not In A Good Way
item.content:encoded:
There‚Äôs been quite a lot of talk recently about the lack of voiceover work in Pokemon Legends: Z-A, and I can understand why. Game Freak has made some pretty decent strides with its cutscenes, depicting characters that animate realistically right down to their facial expressions and mouth movements. Yet they don‚Äôt actually talk. It‚Äôs weird in practice to see such well-constructed scenes play out in near total silence, but that‚Äôs actually not my biggest gripe with the residents of Lumiose City.

If you go into a real-life busy city centre in the middle of the day, one thing you‚Äôll notice is that most people will probably be walking somewhere. Whether they‚Äôre darting from shop to shop, slowly ambling along in chattering groups, or even taking a few steps backwards to pick up the sausage that‚Äôs slipped out of their hotdog bun, everybody‚Äôs moving. Heck, it‚Äôs the reason why cities are often described as ‚Äòbustling‚Äô ‚Äì it literally means ‚Äòfull of activity‚Äô.

Not in Lumiose City, though, oh no. You take a stroll through Legend: Z-A‚Äôs environment, and you‚Äôd be forgiven for thinking Medusa had run amok and turned almost everybody to stone. They just stand still, and it‚Äôs so creepy, man.

Now, I want to acknowledge right off the bat that this isn‚Äôt a new thing; NPCs have always been averse to movement in Pok√©mon games. But there‚Äôs just something about Z-A that makes it more noticeable than ever. My theory is that because Lumiose City is the only major environment, anything that detracts from its sense of place is immediately more glaring. You could almost forgive previous entries for similar infractions because their towns and cities were simply part of a much larger world. Here, the city is the world.

There are so many people, too. I‚Äôve honestly never seen a wider selection of NPCs in a Pok√©mon game, and the fact that 99% of them stand completely still makes for some seriously weird, unsettling imagery. They're not just on pavements too, but in the roads, sitting down for a sip of coffee (not actually drinking though), or standing on the grass, facing in seemingly random directions. It‚Äôs like that scene from M. Night Shyamalan‚Äôs cult classic The Happening where everyone suddenly stops dead in the middle of the street (I‚Äôm joking about the ‚Äòcult classic‚Äô bit ‚Äì it‚Äôs a stinker).

I know everyone‚Äôs made a big fuss about the buildings in Z-A, and I get it, they‚Äôre pretty awful. But in my opinion, you can get away with quite a lot if you actually make it seem like your environment is busy with activity. Go back to the first 3D GTA games if you don‚Äôt believe me. The cities there may look pretty crude by today‚Äôs standards, but of the few pedestrians and vehicles that those games are able to handle in one go, the majority of them are moving in some way. It makes a huge difference.

It‚Äôs not just an aesthetic thing, either. One of the biggest mechanics introduced in Z-A is the ability to sneak up on your fellow trainers and land a move on their Pok√©mon before they‚Äôve even had a chance to respond. So if I can do that, why can‚Äôt they? It would make navigating the Battle Zones so much more interesting and engaging if I knew that an NPC could get the drop on me at any moment. It‚Äôs yet another indication that in the world of Pok√©mon, you‚Äôre the hero, and everyone else is just surface dressing.

I‚Äôm not completely down on Legends: Z-A. I think the overall structure of having specific zones for catching and battling is quite interesting, and the character customisation is frankly the best it's ever been. But man, I‚Äôm so tired of these games feeling so lifeless all the time. Its environments are supposed to convey a sense of excitement and positivity, and I just feel like I‚Äôve been plunged into the middle of a horror movie.

I don't know... Maybe I've been spoiled by games like Cyberpunk 2077 and Hitman: World of Assassination. Or maybe Game Freak needs to get a grip and start making its worlds feel a bit more alive. It's not much to ask, right?

item.title: More Ubisoft Layoffs, This Time at Massive Entertainment
item.content:encoded:
After Ubisoft RedLynx put out a statement today that it was laying off up to 60 members of its staff in a restructuring to focus on "small screens," one of the teams that you could argue is one of Ubisoft's jewel studios for the Snowdrop Engine alone, Ubisoft Massive Entertainment, released a statement confirming its own restructuring, and that it has launched "a voluntary career transition program," which is essentially giving employees a chance to take themselves off the board while still receiving proper severance and support.

"As part of our ongoing evolution and long-term planning, we have recently realigned our teams and resources to strengthen our roadmap, ensuring our continued focus on The Division franchise and the technologies, including Snowdrop and Ubisoft Connect, that power our games," the statement begins.

"To support this transition responsibly, we have introduced a voluntary career transition program, giving eligible team members the opportunity to take their next career step on their own terms, supported by a comprehensive package that includes financial and career assistance."

The statement concludes with Massive Entertainment reiterating it is "fully committed to our roadmap and to creating great experiences for players around the world, including The Division 2, The Division 2: Survivors, The Division Resurgence, and The Division 3."

While Massive Entertainment's recent titles, both Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora and Star Wars Outlaws failed to hit the mark for Ubisoft on a critical and commercial level, what can't be denied is that the studio's Snowdrop Engine is technically impressive, because if nothing else, both Outlaws and Frontiers of Pandora are two of the best-looking games this generation.

It's unfortunate to see more layoffs from Ubisoft today, even when Ubisoft tries to wrap them up in a bow by framing it as employees taking "their next career step on their own terms." Sure, those "eligible" employees might ultimately choose to leave, but being told you're eligible to leave is another way of saying you're no longer wanted.

Beyond the layoffs announced at Ubisoft RedLynx, we've also seen Ubisoft push out veteran developer Marc-Alexis C√¥t√©, who until recently was the head of the Assassin's Creed franchise for the company.

item.title: PowerWash Simulator 2 Review - Suds Up!
item.content:encoded:
Powerwashers, it's time to suit up, as the citizens of Caldera County require your cleaning expertise once again for ample soapy adventures. Developer FuturLab returns with PowerWash Simulator 2, the direct sequel to their 2021 bubbly simulation game, bringing forth new jobs to take on, more equipment to acquire, and new interiors and exteriors in need of a clean.

Following the release of PowerWash Simulator, FuturLab laid out the blueprint for its sequel, which should make way for a host of new content to explore and new adjustments and optimizations for a more squeaky-clean gameplay. As for whether Powerwash Simulator 2 sets itself apart from its predecessor or is more of the same, it's up to the players to decide, but what they can anticipate is plenty of time spent blasting the dirt away, as we did!

Time For A Spring Clean

Let's be honest, as it pertains to the previous sentence: FuturLab doesn't do much to innovate the formula they have set out with PowerWash Simulator in 2021 by comparison. Instead, the developers set out to build upon their sudsy creation by improving the game's graphics and controls, retooling its tools and equipment, and better structuring their maps for a smooth gameplay experience.

As the owner of a powerwashing company in Caldera County, players will lend their hand to fellow residents through various jobs they'll undertake by cleaning multiple objects and buildings from a shooting gallery, a road sweeper, a few houses, and yes, even a public toilet. Luckily, they'll have a few things to help them on these jobs to make accessibility more seamless and guide them in completing them for their clients.

There's also a story in play whose foundations were laid in the first game, with an Ancient Statue, and it continues in its sequel, as it has some paranormal origins. Players will gain insight into this mystery through character dialogue in text messages and article clippings, which will help them piece it together.

"Boom And The Dirt Is Gone"

Admittedly, every player will have a method for cleaning objects and structures in PowerWash Simulator 2, and mine was to clean from top to bottom and in a clockwise direction, for my OCD's sake. While my approach may be rather meticulous, perhaps bordering on obsessive, cleaning, or in this case, power washing, is cathartic and helps unwind or unpack the mind.

As relaxing as it is to blast away the dirt from the rooftops to the walls and on the ground, from a gameplay perspective, the maps that feature in every story job that players will undertake have been structured similarly to the first game, where, upon accepting a job, players blast away the dirt and grime from all surfaces. However, there are a few areas that are rather tricky to clean, like between joints, handles, drains, and the underside of vehicles, which will demand plenty of time for players to get clean.

While as frustrating as it may be when trying to determine which areas were amiss, a tracker can be accessed where players can mark which areas have not been thoroughly cleaned. Likewise, hitting a button or key can reveal the remaining dirt spots or unclean areas before aiming our power washer tool to wash the dirt away.

Meanwhile, buildings and other structures will be a much easier feat to accomplish, especially when utilizing various equipment pieces, such as jumping atop platforms, climbing ladders, and the new scissor lift, to reach and clean the rooftops, thus making our time on the job well spent. For floors and rooftops, perhaps the most useful tool of them all, the SwirlForce Surf Ace surface cleaner and its attachments ensure that the surfaces are cleaned extremely well and in a quicker time, too.

Although players will have to spend their hard-earned money to splash on the SwirlForce Surf Ace surface cleaner and other cleaners with their attachments over time, players can find their favorite tools of the trade. The tool wheel allows players to access all acquired cleaners and their attachments to find the best tool for the job or for the task at hand, whether it be for flat surfaces or cleaning the tricky nooks and crannies.

On the latter, not every job will go smoothly, as there will be some challenging jobs to tackle, like the shooting gallery, a literal billboard, a cement truck, and a shopping mall, which will throw players for a loop. While the task at hand may be daunting, having a plan of action and the right tools will make these jobs less intimidating while cleaning these precarious surfaces less arduous.

Despite the frustrations one may have with these complicated surfaces, which can be time-consuming, there is fun to be had, such as on the billboard map, where players can use a new piece of equipment, the abseiling apparatus. While high up in the sky, players can move up and down and left to right while being seated; however, the only restriction is that trying to clean the platform below will force you to disembark, so it's slightly limiting in its utility.

One of the welcoming changes to the washers and their attachments is that once they've surpassed their functionality, they can be sold, which wasn't possible in the first game. This, in turn, will allow players to recover funds to purchase more effective and powerful washers for more challenging jobs as they progress in the story.

Another new change, or rather addition, is customization according to the sequel's story, and the expansion of their cleaning business; they'll move into new premises that can be personalized. You reorganize the shop where players can purchase furniture, which must also be cleaned before using the Placement Mode to reposition and place them within their business space.

And for the best possible experience, players have the option to choose between Classic and Modern controls, which have just a few differences between them, but for experienced washers, the Classic controls will be more akin to their experiences with the first PowerWash Simulator game. Likewise, the Free Play and split-screen co-op modes return, allowing players to revisit completed maps and team up with another player for the ultimate couch co-op experience.

Not Entirely Spotless...

One desire for the sequel was to up the ante, but unfortunately, it follows the same formula as the first game, and its gameplay can feel repetitive at times, almost in a loop of doing the same things over and over again. While it stays true to its formula and boasts a few new additions along with new adjustments and optimizations that change the formula ever so slightly, PowerWash Simulator 2 is more of a continuation of the first game rather than a sequel.

Mind you, there are some long-awaited adjustments and optimizations, such as soap retooling, reselling of washers and attachments, new tools and equipment, improved controls and graphics, alongside the new maps and customization, gameplay is much the same. Yes, it's very much PowerWash Simulator, but with a fresh coat of paint, it's still plenty of fun engaging with the content, blasting all the dirt and grime off surfaces, and having a variety of tools at our disposal.

Sure, the details are in the small things that give PowerWash Simulator 2 quite the upgrade from its predecessor. The developer didn't do much to evolve the game completely, but they have done enough to make it a standout release in the PowerWash Simulator series. And players won't be disappointed with this latest offering, with plenty of new content and a host of changes that will keep them engulfed in bubbly fun for hours on end.

PowerWash Simulator 2 Review | Final Thoughts

With tens of hours invested in PowerWash Simulator 2, one will certainly continue their soapy adventures and expand their powerwashing business in Caldera County. Having spent hours and hours in the first game and enjoying all the DLCs that were added post-launch, suffice to say, that there is an excitement towards the sequel, and I was genuinely surprised with what the developers offered in the sequel, even if it doesn't appear to be a sequel in the traditional sense.

Quite simply, FuturLab took the formula and the best parts from the first game, adding much-needed new content, adjustments, and optimizations for a more complete power-washing experience. What many are most looking forward to once they've rolled the credits is whether they'll follow a similar post-launch roadmap in adding free and paid content to the game in the form of DLCs, adding more variety to the game, and continued investment from the players.

It will certainly be interesting to see where PowerWash Simulator 2 will be in the future, both short-term and long-term, and if the developers are following the success story of its predecessor. The future is undoubtedly bright and bubbly. Now, if only a particular achievement didn't get bugged, preventing me from unlocking it, but for once, we'll blame the gnomes for this!

Borderlands 4 launched at $69.99 (eventually, after a weird kerfuffle online about whether it would jump to $80), with the Deluxe Edition priced $99.99 and the Super Deluxe Edition at $129.99. At its launch in September 2019, Borderlands 3 cost $59.99 for the standard edition, $79.99 for the Deluxe Edition, and $99.99 for the Super Deluxe Edition. It's also worth noting that Borderlands 3 was a PC exclusive to the Epic Games Store for six months after its release, whereas Borderlands 4 launched across PC via Steam as well as consoles.

So, we don‚Äôt have hard sales figures yet (2K Games has made no announcement so far). But according to Circana, Borderlands 4 was the first Borderlands title to launch as the best-selling game of its release month, so there‚Äôs that.

item.title: NVIDIA Shows DLSS 4, Path Tracing, and RTX Mega Geometry with New Downloadable Bonsai Diorama Demo
item.content:encoded:
NVIDIA has released a new downloadable 'Bonsai Diorama' demo that shows off DLSS 4, path tracing, and RTX Mega Geometry. The Bonsai Diorama demo accompanies the latest update of the Unreal Engine RTX branch (version 5.6.1), showcasing RTX Mega Geometry alongside ReSTIR PT (which just received performance and image quality improvements) and the full DLSS 4 technology suite (DLSS Super Resolution, DLSS Ray Reconstruction, and DLSS Frame Generation).

If you wish to try the demo, NVIDIA says the minimum graphics card is a GeForce RTX 2080Ti, while the recommended one is the GeForce RTX 5060. Also, you should be using the GeForce driver 581.29 or newer.

NVIDIA also warns that the resolution and window settings can only be adjusted in the main menu, before actually launching into the Bonsai Diorama demo level. You should start the demo with full screen; if using an 8 GB GPU, start with 1080p or 1440p. If you use an 11 GB GPU or higher, try 4K resolution.

Once in the demo, you can toggle the user interface by pressing H. Here, you can toggle RTX Mega Geometry and Ray Reconstruction on and off and tweak DLSS Super Resolution (Off, DLAA, Auto, Quality, Balanced, Performance, Ultra Performance) and Frame Generation (Off, Auto, 2x, 3x, 4x).

The main feature being showcased here is really RTX Mega Geometry, which debuted in Remedy's Alan Wake 2 with a patch showing performance improvements. In this case, though, NVIDIA focuses on the image quality benefits:

RTX Mega Geometry adds full quality Nanite geometry to the ray tracing bounding volume hierarchy (BVH). As a result, ray traced shadows and reflections no longer exhibit visual artifacts typically present with Unreal Engine 5's default behavior.

A webinar is scheduled for Thursday, October 28, at 10 AM Pacific Time. Developers will be able to ask questions about the Bonsai Diorama demo and its featured technologies.

In other NVIDIA news, ACE (Avatar Cloud Engine) can now use the open-source Qwen3-8B AI model as an In-Game Inferencing (IGI) SDK plug-in. This simplifies integration within a developer's pipeline and optimizes the simultaneous processing of AI and graphics for accelerated game performance. Qwen3 enables developers to create enhanced game characters that can reason in real time through non-scripted events and respond dynamically to player inputs and contextual information.

Alongside the release of Qwen3-8B, NVIDIA also made several improvements to the core IGI SDK:

  • MultiLORA adapters to quickly fine-tune model weights with minimal computational overhead
  • CUDA support for graphics with Vulkan backends, which optimizes graphics and AI workloads for accelerated performance when both are running simultaneously.

item.title: Battlefield 6 Season 1 Preview - California Dreaming
item.content:encoded:
With Battlefield 6 out now and doing quite well for itself in the multiplayer action sphere ‚Äì as we detailed in our full review ‚Äì it‚Äôs time to turn our attention towards what‚Äôs next for EA‚Äôs biggest game of the year. We‚Äôre just under a week away from Season 1. Launching on October 28 and across three phases over time in an effort to bring high-quality content to players at regular intervals.

The first phase of content will open with Rogue Ops, which includes a new map known as Blackwell Fields, and a new 4v4 mode called Strikepoint. In the second phase, starting on November 18, we‚Äôll see California Resistance and the addition of another new map called Eastwood.

Then, on December 9, Winter Offensive will begin with a seasonal update to the existing Empire State map.

Each Battlefield 6 season will include new weapons, maps, modes, as well as vehicles, and more. All of this content is being promised for free from the start, or is earnable on free tiers in the Battle Pass.

Digging into Rogue Ops specifically, it‚Äôs themed around high-stakes ops in pursuit of military secrets in the first all-new map: Blackwell Fields. While it‚Äôs a large map set in the Californian Chaparral and built for all-out warfare, there‚Äôs a good amount of structures that lean heavily into standoff with outdoor combat.

We got to try out this map in the Close-Quarters Battle mode, which meant smaller team sizes and up close and personal fights. Right away, it‚Äôs easy to see why this map is ideal for the selected mode. 

You can duck in and out of military installations and homesteads scattered across the land. Everything is dusty and dirty, and fires scatter the area, which makes it harder to see clearly in some aspects.

New weapons available during this phase include the SCAR SC .300, which excels at close-quarters combat. There‚Äôs also the Glock 22 and the Mini Fix Bolt-Action rifle for long-distance attacks.

There‚Äôs also a new vehicle available ‚Äì an APC called the Traverser Mark 2, which operates as an Infantry Support vehicle that offers up a spawn point and a supply station or other vehicles on your team. Rogue Ops and the Blackwell Fields map will run from October 28 to November 11, with Phase 2 to follow.

California Resistance is an apt name for the next round of Season 1 because it further explores another area of the region where both NATO and the local militia are trying to defend California from PAX‚Äôs incursion. 

The map coming up here is called Eastwood, is set in a quiet and upscale Southern California neighborhood ‚Äì well, formerly quiet because now there‚Äôs a warzone running through it, and every part of it can be chaotic but also used to your advantage.

Trying out the All-Out-Warfare mode, it‚Äôs easy to see how this area has become a complete battlefield, and you‚Äôll be fighting in and around houses, blowing them apart, and riding around in tanks and other vehicles to add to the destruction.

This phase will also introduce a limited-time mode to Battlefield 6 called Sabotage, in which two teams of eight attack and defend supply caches on the map. Attackers and defenders will swap sides after each round to mix things up, and destroying the most caches will net a win for the match.

Battle Pickups will also debut during this phase, which are high-value, rare weapons with limited ammunition but can do major damage to enemies. 

New weapons will include the DP-12 shotgun, which has different ammo types in each of its tubes, and the 8-shot S&W M327 revolver.

Phase 3 of the season will turn towards winter, and while details remain sparse for now, it‚Äôll launch ahead of the holidays with a winter-themed Empire State map. Following that, players can expect Season 2 to drop within the new year.

In 2006, Scarface: The World is Yours was released as an alternate timeline sequel to the classic 1983 film starring Al Pacino as Tony Montana. As reported by PC Gamer, Scarface: The World is Yours was accidentally released early on Epic Games Store, and the game page is still active. It's also listed on Steam, which included an explanation for the early release.

"Due to a technical issue during backend configuration, the game was unintentionally pushed live on a different platform earlier than planned. We want to clarify that our intended long-term release platform includes Steam, and we're now accelerating our efforts to finalize this version," the statement reads.

Because Scarface went live prematurely, Wario64 and others noted that it includes two fan-made patches, SilentPatch and Fusion Fix, which make the game playable. The creator of SilentPatch, Silent, notes that the patches were incorporated into this release without permission, but also acknowledges that it wasn't "necessary as per the license, but would be nice."

Attempts to reach EC Digital didn't turn up any contact info, and it's unknown if Universal sanctioned this re-release. Following the initial reports, EC Digital has shared a statement on Steam that it has asked Valve to temporarily hide the page "while we worked through ongoing licensing and technical matters."

item.title: Exclusive Games Are "Antiquated," Xbox President Says
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The idea of exclusive games in 2025 is "antiquated," according to Xbox president Sarah Bond. She said in a new interview that people are beginning to "evolve way past" the idea that a game should be exclusive to one store or device.

"The biggest games in the world are available everywhere. You look at Call of Duty, you look at Minecraft, you look at Fortnite, you look at Roblox ... that's actually what's really driving community in gaming. That's where people gather. And the idea of locking it to one store or one device is antiquated for most people," she told Mashable.

"You want to be able to play with your friends anywhere, regardless of what they're on. And we're really leaning into that with this experience [Rog Ally X]. It just opens up another way for you to play, as does cloud, as does PC as do the consoles we all have in the living room," she added.

Microsoft was once a big believer in exclusive games, but the company has updated its business strategy and has in recent times opted to release its games in more places, including rival systems.

For Sony, the company has also begun to bring more of its games to places beyond PlayStation, including PC and, in the case of Helldivers 2, Xbox. Nintendo, however, only releases its own games for its own exclusive platforms, and that's proven to be good business for the company.

Microsoft does not have one single strategy it applies to all of its game releases, as some titles are released across multiple platforms simultaneously, others are not. One of the next Xbox games that could make the jump to PlayStation is Starfield, with a report saying this will be announced in 2026.

In other news, Microsoft is reportedly gearing up to announce a Halo: Combat Evolved remake, and it might be in the works for PS5.

Microsoft was also in the news recently regarding Bond's comments about the next Xbox console, labeling it "high-end" and prompting fears from fans that it will be very expensive.

item.title: Ubisoft Massive initiates voluntary buyouts
item.content:encoded:
Ubisoft has announced another staff reduction across its global network of studios, with today's second culling taking place at Massive Entertainment.

This is taking the form of a voluntary buyout, or as Ubisoft referred to it in a statement to Game Developer, a "voluntary career transition program." It's being offered to "eligible" employees so they can take "their next career step on their own terms." The program includes an offer of a a "comprehensive package" that includes "financial and career assistance."

The announcement also came with quiet confirmation for the fate of Massive-led franchises like Star Wars Outlaws and Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora. Ubisoft said that Massive is "fully committed" to working on the Tom Clancy's The Division series, including The Division 2, the mobile game The Division Resurgence, and The Division 3. 

The studio's licensed Star Wars and Avatar games are not mentioned.

Ubisoft has laid off many workers in its massive business transition

Ubisoft has spent 2024 restructuring its business following two years of underperforming titles like Star Wars Outlaws and lengthy, expensive game development cycles like the kind that led to a major delay for Assassin's Creed Shadows.

The highest-profile change has been the creation of Vantage Studios in a joint partnership with Tencent, which now houses the Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, and Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege series. The company allegedly ousted Assassin's Creed series lead Marc-Alexis C√¥t√© just last week.

But before Vantage Studios formally came on line, the company spent two years laying off workers and shutting down offices in locations like London, Leamington, and San Francisco. item.title: No More Robot‚Äôs new cruise ship management sim is hella bleak, despite the input of former Overcooked devs
item.content:encoded:
At least the Flying Dutchman didn't have a bingo hall

Whenever I find myself growing grim about the mouth, whenever it is a damp, drizzly October in my soul, I account it high time to get to sea as soon as I can. Specifically, I dream of cruise liners. I‚Äôve never been on an ocean cruise, but I‚Äôve been on at least two North Sea ferries and in my mind, cruise ships are paradise.

They are places of luxury and possibly a few exotic murders - ocean-going adventurelands that perversely harbour swimming pools and waterslides. Imagine it, a boat with a pool. Such delicious unreason. Here to disabuse me of these visions is No More Robot‚Äôs Cruise Control, which makes cruise ships look like hell.

It's a management sim created by a team who include former Overcooked developers, but for all the ability to construct "fine dining" facilities, I see little of Overcooked‚Äôs saucy joyfulness in the trailer. I see suffocating bingo halls and arcade machines crammed together like tombstones. I see crowds so dense the people have no choice but to walk through each other.

I see trash and vomit and despairing janitors. I see carpet patterns that follow like a tedious argument of insidious intent. I see potted cinemas that resemble factory farm incubators. I see dollar signs floating up from smiling, empty heads. Worst of all, I can‚Äôt see any waterslides or swimming pools.

You wish to know what it‚Äôs like to participate in this inhumane simulation, this abject spawn of the Bermuda triangle? Very well. Cruise Control looks like a familiar rhythm of ensuring your ship has the facilities to keep your customers happy, while avoiding long queues to attractions and mechanical breakdowns. The more guests you serve, the more amenities you‚Äôll acquire and upgrade. Perhaps there‚Äôs a waterslide to unlock, once enough bodies have been fed to the dancefloors. Fail to amuse the clientele sufficiently, and they'll send you direct to Davey Jones' Locker. Fools! We are all already there.

You can read more on Steam. It‚Äôs out in 2026, and is the work of Not Tonight developers No More Robots. No More Robots are also publishers ‚Äì their recent signings include Little Rocket Lab, a Stardew factory sim that I have downloaded the demo for and feel guilty about not playing yet. Final anecdote: I have a musician friend who once worked on a cruise liner. He lives on a boat now. I'm not sure he's really my friend. Perhaps my friend is still out there, queuing for bingo in the doldrums, and some creature of the deep sea has stolen his face.
